idea_plan.idea_summary: An object starts from rest and is subject to a force described by a Force-Time graph which has a positive region followed by a negative region of equal area. The candidate must determine the final displacement and velocity state of the object.
constraints_used: value at a point (starts from rest)
inequality / bound (area of positive region equals area of negative region)
what_is_asked: compare two quantities (final vs initial position/velocity)
intended_wrong_paths: Interpreting the graph as Velocity-Time (concluding the object returns to the start).
Interpreting the graph as Displacement-Time (concluding the object moved out and back).
Correctly identifying zero final velocity but incorrectly assuming zero net displacement because the "net force" area is zero.
idea_plan.difficulty_rationale: It requires a two-step conceptual integration: Force → Acceleration → Velocity (Area 1) → Displacement (Area 2). The candidate must realize that while the net change in momentum is zero (stops at the end), the velocity was positive throughout the entire motion, implying maximum displacement rather than zero displacement.

mcq_viability.reason: The distractors map perfectly to different levels of derivative confusion (treating F as v, or F as x), creating distinct, plausible physical descriptions.

idea_plan._raw_text:
schema_id: P3
idea_summary: >
  An object starts from rest and is subject to a force described by a Force-Time graph which has a positive region followed by a negative region of equal area. The candidate must determine the final displacement and velocity state of the object.
function_or_object_type:
  - physical system
  - piecewise continuous function
constraints_used:
  - value at a point (starts from rest)
  - inequality / bound (area of positive region equals area of negative region)
what_is_asked:
  - compare two quantities (final vs initial position/velocity)
intended_wrong_paths:
  - Interpreting the graph as Velocity-Time (concluding the object returns to the start).
  - Interpreting the graph as Displacement-Time (concluding the object moved out and back).
  - Correctly identifying zero final velocity but incorrectly assuming zero net displacement because the "net force" area is zero.
difficulty_rationale: >
  It requires a two-step conceptual integration: Force → Acceleration → Velocity (Area 1) → Displacement (Area 2). The candidate must realize that while the net change in momentum is zero (stops at the end), the velocity was positive throughout the entire motion, implying maximum displacement rather than zero displacement.
mcq_viability:
  viable: yes
  reason: >
    The distractors map perfectly to different levels of derivative confusion (treating F as v, or F as x), creating distinct, plausible physical descriptions.
